facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1952. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd March, 1951,

facts.text: Appeal from High Court of Calcutta judgment dated 22nd March 1951 by Harries C.J. and Banerjee J. in Reference No. 4 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd March, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta  Harries C.J. and Banerjee J.  in Reference No. 4 of 1950 .

facts.text: First respondent purchased entire Touzi No. 341 of 24-Parganas Collectorate at revenue sale on January 9, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent herein  hereinafter referred to as the respondent  purchased the entire Touzi No. 341 of the 24-Parganas Collectorate at a revenue sale held on ,January 9, 1942.

facts.text: Purchaser acquired right under section 37 of Bengal Revenue Sales Act, 1859 to avoid and annul all under-tenures and eject all under-tenants with exceptions.

anchor.surface_text: As such purchaser, the respondent acquired under section 37 of the Bengal Revenue Sales Act, 1859  Central Act No. 11 of 1859  the right to avoid and annul all under-tenures and forthwith to eject all under- tenants-with certain exceptions

facts.text: Respondent gave notices of ejectment and brought suit in 1946 to evict under-tenants including second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of that right the respondent gave numberices of ejectment and brought a suit in 1946 to evict certain under-tenants, including the second respondent herein, and to recover possession of. the lands.

facts.text: Suit decreed against second respondent who appealed to District Judge, 24-Parganas.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was. decreed against the second respondent who preferred an appeal to the District Judge, 24-Parganas, Contending that his undertenure came within one of the exceptions referred to in section 37.

facts.text: West Bengal Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 introduced on March 23, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was pending, the Bill, which was later passed as the West Bengal Revenue Sales  West . Bengal Amendment  Act, 1950,  hereinafter referred to asthe amending Act  was introduced in the West Bengal Legislative Assembly on March 23, 1950.

facts.text: Amending Act came into force on March 15, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Bill was eventually passed as the amending Act and it .came into force on.March 15, 1950.

facts.text: Section 7 of amending Act provided that all pending suits, appeals and proceedings abate unless resulted in delivery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: It substituted by section 4 thenew section 37 in the place of the original section 37, and it provided by section 7 that all pending suits, appeals and other proceedings which had number already resulted in delivery of possession shall abate.

facts.text: Respondent moved High Court under article 228 claiming section 7 void under articles 19(1)(f) and 31.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent, companytending that section 7 wasvoid as abriging his fundamental fights under article 19 1   f  and article 31, moved the High Court under article 228 to withdraw the pending appeal and determine the companystitutional issue .

facts.text: High Court withdrew appeal, heard case, declared section 7 unconstitutional and void, returned to District Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal accordingly. withdrawn and the case was heard by Trevor Harries C.J. and Banerjee J who, by separate but, companycurring judgments, declared section 7 unconstitutional and void and. returned the case to the District Court for disposal,

facts.text: High Court held retrospective deprivation of vested right without abatement of price infringes article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that the respondents right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants being a vested right acquired by him under his purchase before section 37 was amended, the retrospective deprivation of that right by section 7 of the amending Act without any abatement of the price paid

facts.text: Suit instituted on 18th March 1946 as Title Suit No. 35 of 1946 in Fourth Court of Subordinate Judge at Alipore.

anchor.surface_text: instituted a suit, being Title Suit No. 35 of 1946, in the Fourth Court of the Subordinate Judge at Alipore 24-Parganahs for the ejectment of respondents Nos. 2 to 6,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed suit on 14th February 1949 against defendant No.1 (respondent No.2).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge who tried the suit delivered his judgment on the 14th February, 1949. By that judgment he overruled the companytentions of the companytesting defendant and passed a decree for ejectment against him.

facts.text: Appeal filed on 25th March 1949 as Title Appeal No. 252 of 1949 to District Judge Alipore.

anchor.surface_text: On the 25th March, 1949, the respondent No. 2 preferred an appeal, being Title Appeal No. 252 of 1949, before the District Judge at Alipore, 24Parganahs.

facts.text: West Bengal Act VII of 1950 assented on 15th March 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the West Bengal Legislature passed West Bengal Act VII of 1950, called the Bengal Land Revenue Sales  West Bengal Amendment  Act of 1950, which received the assent of the Governor of Bengal on the 15th March, 1950,

facts.text: High Court on 22nd March 1951 held section 7 void under article 19(1)(f) read with 19(5).

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd March, 1951, the High Court held that section 7 imposed an unreasonable restriction on the respondent Subodh Gopal Boses right to hold property and violated his fundamental right guaranteed by article 19  1   f

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court judgment on December 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. December 17. The following Judgments were delivered.

facts.text: Statement of objects: Hardship caused by s.37 in urban areas like Calcutta due to land value increase leading to evictions.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear, according to the .statement 0f objects and reasons annexed to the Bill, that great hardship was being caused to a large section of the people by the. application of section 37 of the Bengal Land Revenue Sales Act, 1859, in the urban areas and particularly in Calcutta and its suburbs where the present phenomenal increase

facts.text: New section 37 enlarges exceptions but allows enhancement of rent for newly protected tenures.

anchor.surface_text: the purchaser shall be entitled to proceed in the manner prescribed by any law for the time being in force for the determination of a fair and equitable rent of such tenure, holding or lease.

facts.text: Supreme Court held section 7 does not amount to deprivation under article 31.

anchor.surface_text: I find it difficult to hold that the abridgement sought to. be effected retrospectively of the rights of a purchaser at a revenue sale is so substantial as to amount to a deprivation of his property within the meaning of article 31  1  and  2 .

facts.text: DAS J. held restriction reasonable under article 19(5) considering circumstances like land value rise and evictions.

issues.text: Whether section 7 of the West Bengal Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 is unconstitutional and void as imposing an unreasonable restriction on the respondent's fundamental right to hold property under Article 19(1)(f) not saved by Article 19(5)?

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent, companytending that section 7 wasvoid as abriging his fundamental fights under article 19 1   f  and article 31, moved the High Court under article 228 to withdraw the pending appeal. The learned Judges held that the respondents right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants being a vested right acquired by him under his purchase before section 37 was amended, the retrospective deprivation of that right by section 7

issues.text: Whether the respondent's right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants acquired under section 37 of the Bengal Revenue Sales Act, 1859 constitutes 'property' within the meaning of Article 19(1)(f) and Article 31(1), such that deprivation by section 7 is lawful under authority of law?

anchor.surface_text: As such purchaser, the respondent acquired under section 37 of the Bengal Revenue Sales Act, 1859  Central Act No. 11 of 1859  the right to avoid and annul all under-tenures and forthwith to eject all under- tenants-with certain exceptions. [...] On behalf of the appellant State the learned Attorney-General contended before us that if, as the respondent claims, his right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants [...] was property within the meaning of clause (1) Of article 19, then, it was also property within the meaning of clause (1) of article 31

issues.text: Whether Article 19(1)(f) protects concrete rights to specific property or only the general freedom or capacity of citizens to acquire, hold and dispose of property?

anchor.surface_text: It will be convenient to deal first with the latter contention of the Attorney-General. Sub-clause f 0f clause 1 of article 19 has, in my opinion, noapplication to the case. That article enumerates certain freedoms under the caption right to freedom and deals with those great and basic rights which are recognised and guaranteed as the natural rights inherent in the status of a citizen of a free country.

issues.text: Whether clauses (1) and (2) of Article 31 deal with mutually exclusive kinds of deprivation of property or must be read together as protecting against deprivation except by acquisition or taking possession with compensation?

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd March, 1951, the High Court held that section 7 imposed an unreasonable restriction [...] and was, therefore void under article 13 1. [...] Turning next to the contention based on article 31 1 , it Was put thus in the language of Das J. in Chiranjit Lal Choudhurys case [...] Article 31 1 formulates the fundamental right in negative form prohibiting the deprivation of property except by authority of law.

issues.text: Whether the abridgement of the purchaser's rights under the retrospective operation of sections 4 and 7 of the amending Act amounts to a deprivation of property under Article 31(1) and (2)?

anchor.surface_text: I find it difficult to hold that the abridgement sought to. be effected retrospectively of the rights of a purchaser at a revenue sale is so substantial as to amount to a deprivation of his property within the meaning of article 31  1  and  2 .

issues.text: Whether section 7 of the amending Act violates Article 31(2) by depriving the purchaser of property without compensation?

holdings.text: Article 19(1)(f) has no application to concrete rights in specific property; it protects the general freedom or capacity of citizens to acquire, hold and dispose of property, distinct from protection of specific property rights under Article 31.

anchor.surface_text: It will be convenient to deal first with the latter contention of the Attorney-General. Sub-clause f 0f clause 1 of article 19 has, in my opinion, noapplication to the case. That article enumerates certain freedoms under the caption right to freedom and deals with those great and basic rights which are recognised and guaranteed as the natural rights inherent in the status of a citizen of a free country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation distinguishing freedoms in Art 19 from property rights in Art 31; analogy to US privileges/immunities, UN Human Rights Declaration, GOI Act 1935; policy considerations avoiding double protection and enabling social control.

holdings.text: Clauses (1) and (2) of Article 31 must be read together as protecting against deprivation by acquisition or taking possession with compensation; they are not mutually exclusive, and clause (1) requires legislative authority while clause (2) adds public purpose and compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Turning next to the contention based on article 31 1 , it Was put thus in the language of Das J. in Chiranjit Lal Choudhurys case [...] Article 31 1 formulates the fundamental right in negative form prohibiting the deprivation of property except by authority of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects obiter from Chiranjit Lal; harmonious construction avoiding redundancy and arbitrary power; purposive to protect against state invasion; distinguishes police power/eminent domain; legislative lists and historical context.

holdings.text: The abridgement of purchaser's rights to annul under-tenures and eject under-tenants by retrospective operation of sections 4 and 7 of the West Bengal Revenue Sales (Amendment) Act, 1950, does not amount to a deprivation of property under Article 31(1) and (2).

anchor.surface_text: I find it difficult to hold that the abridgement sought to. be effected retrospectively of the rights of a purchaser at a revenue sale is so substantial as to amount to a deprivation of his property within the meaning of article 31 1  and  2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies test of substantial abridgement impairing possession/enjoyment/value; new s37 enlarges exceptions but allows rent enhancement; compares old/new s37; not acquisition/possession.

holdings.text: Section 7 of the West Bengal Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 does not impose unreasonable restriction under Article 19(1)(f) read with 19(5); High Court judgment declaring it void is set aside; appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: the cumulative effect of the foregoing facts which were number placed before the High Court much outweighs the companysideration of the pecuniary loss of the respondent, Subodh Gopal Bose, as the auction- purchaser and in the circumstances the infliction of the loss of the right to eject under-tenants can only be regarded as a reasonable restriction

holdings.reasoning_summary: DAS J: considers circumstances (land value rise, evictions, statement of objects, ordinance urgency, pending cases, rent enhancement); outweighs purchaser loss; CJI: Art19 inapplicable, no deprivation under Art31.

holdings.text: The right to annul under-tenures and eject under-tenants under s37 Bengal Revenue Sales Act is not 'property' protected under Article 19(1)(f) such that retrospective deprivation by s7 requires scrutiny thereunder; falls under Article 31.
